message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Diversity begets stability: Sublinear growth and competitive coexistence across ecosystems
Paper Abstract: The worldwide loss of species diversity brings urgency to understanding how diverse ecosystems maintain stability. Whereas early ecological ideas and classic observations suggested that stability increases with diversity, ecological theory makes the opposite prediction, leading to the long-standing “diversity-stability debate.” Here, we show that this puzzle can be resolved if growth scales as a sublinear power law with biomass (exponent <1), exhibiting a form of population self-regulation analogous to models of individual ontogeny. We show that competitive interactions among populations with sublinear growth do not lead to exclusion, as occurs with logistic growth, but instead promote stability at higher diversity. Our model realigns theory with classic observations and predicts large-scale macroecological patterns. However, it makes an unsettling prediction: Biodiversity loss may accelerate the destabilization of ecosystems.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

I've completed the web search for "Species diversity ecology." Here are the key findings:

## Definition and Basics

Species diversity is the number of different species that are represented in a given community. Species diversity may include species richness, taxonomic or phylogenetic diversity, and/or species evenness.

## Measuring Species Diversity

Common diversity indices include species richness, the Shannon index, the Simpson index, and the complement of the Simpson index (also known as the Gini-Simpson index). Species diversity is the relationship between species evenness and species richness.

## Ecological Importance

The diversity of species and genes in ecological communities affects the functioning of these communities. More biologically diverse communities appear to be more productive (in terms of biomass production) than are less diverse communities, and they appear to be more stable in the face of perturbations.

## Global Patterns

Species richness, or biodiversity, increases from the poles to the tropics for a wide variety of terrestrial and marine organisms, often referred to as the latitudinal diversity gradient. Tropical forest ecosystems cover less than one-fifth of Earth's terrestrial area and contain about 50% of the world's species.

The search results provide comprehensive information about how species diversity is defined, measured, and its ecological significance in various ecosystems.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Power law scaling"

Links: [{"title":"Power law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_law"},{"title":"Neural scaling law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_scaling_law"},{"title":"Dennard scaling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dennard_scaling"},{"title":"Stream power law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stream_power_law"},{"title":"Quantum computing scaling laws - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_computing_scaling_laws"},{"title":"Kleiber's law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kleiber's_law"},{"title":"Moore's law - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moore's_law"},{"title":"Rain attenuation frequency scaling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rain_attenuation_frequency_scaling"},{"title":"Shortcut model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shortcut_model"},{"title":"Scale-free network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scale-free_network"}]

## Power Law Scaling

Based on the search results, here's an overview of power law scaling:

### Definition

In statistics, a power law is a functional relationship between two quantities, where a relative change in one quantity results in a relative change in the other quantity proportional to the change raised to a constant exponent: one quantity varies as a power of another.(no content)The change is independent of the initial size of those quantities.

### Examples

A simple illustration: The area of a square has a power law relationship with the length of its side, since if the length is doubled, the area is multiplied by 2², while if the length is tripled, the area is multiplied by 3², and so on.

### Real-World Applications

Power law scaling appears across many domains. The distributions of a wide variety of physical, biological, and human-made phenomena approximately follow a power law over a wide range of magnitudes: these include the sizes of craters on the moon and of solar flares, cloud sizes, the foraging pattern of various species, the sizes of activity patterns of neuronal populations, the frequencies of words in most languages, frequencies of family names, the species richness in clades of organisms, the sizes of power outages, volcanic eruptions, human judgments of stimulus intensity and many other quantities.

### Theoretical Significance

The equivalence of power laws with a particular scaling exponent can have a deeper origin in the dynamical processes that generate the power-law relation. In physics, for example, phase transitions in thermodynamic systems are associated with the emergence of power-law distributions of certain quantities, whose exponents are referred to as the critical exponents of the system.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Ecosystem stability"

Links: [{"title":"Ecological stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_stability"},{"title":"Alternative stable state - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_stable_state"},{"title":"Ecological effects of biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_effects_of_biodiversity"},{"title":"Resistance (ecology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Resistance_(ecology)"},{"title":"Evelyn Chrystalla Pielou - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evelyn_Chrystalla_Pielou"},{"title":"Hainan black crested gibbon - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hainan_black_crested_gibbon"}]

Here are the search results for "Ecosystem stability":

## Overview

In ecology, an ecosystem is said to possess ecological stability (or equilibrium) if it is capable of returning to its equilibrium state after a perturbation or does not experience unexpected large changes in its characteristics across time.

## Key Concepts and Definitions

The concept of ecosystem stability is complex and multifaceted. In 1997, Grimm and Wissel made an inventory of 167 definitions used in the literature and found 70 different stability concepts.(no content)One strategy proposed to clarify the subject is to replace ecological stability with more specific terms, such as constancy, resilience and persistence.

More specifically, researchers identified stability as three fundamental properties: "staying essentially unchanged", "returning to the reference state after a temporary disturbance" and "persistence through time of an ecological system."

## Diversity and Stability

The relationship between diversity and stability has been widely studied, and diversity can enhance the stability of ecosystem functions at various ecological scales. For example, more biologically diverse communities appear to be more productive than are less diverse communities, and they appear to be more stable in the face of perturbations.

## Alternative Stable States

The theory of alternative stable states predicts that ecosystems can exist under multiple "states" (sets of unique biotic and abiotic conditions).(no content)Ecosystems may transition from one stable state to another, in what is known as a state shift, when perturbed.

More specifically, researchers identified stability as three fundamental properties: "staying essentially unchanged", "returning to the reference state after a temporary disturbance" and "persistence through time of an ecological system."

## Diversity and Stability

The relationship between diversity and stability has been widely studied, and diversity can enhance the stability of ecosystem functions at various ecological scales. For example, more biologically diverse communities appear to be more productive than are less diverse communities, and they appear to be more stable in the face of perturbations.

## Alternative Stable States

The theory of alternative stable states predicts that ecosystems can exist under multiple "states" (sets of unique biotic and abiotic conditions).(no content)Ecosystems may transition from one stable state to another, in what is known as a state shift, when perturbed.

Web search results for query: "Population self-regulation biology"

Links: [{"title":"Self-regulation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-regulation"},{"title":"Biopolitics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biopolitics"},{"title":"Density dependence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density_dependence"},{"title":"Self-limiting (biology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-limiting_(biology)"},{"title":"Biological rules - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biological_rules"},{"title":"Population ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_ecology"},{"title":"Self-organization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-organization"},{"title":"Selfish genetic element - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Selfish_genetic_element"},{"title":"Source–sink dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Source–sink_dynamics"},{"title":"Limiting factor - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regulating_factors"}]

Here are the search results for "Population self-regulation biology":

## Key Concepts Related to Population Self-Regulation

**Self-Limiting Organisms:**
A self-limiting organism or colony of organisms limits its own growth by its actions, such as when a single organism has a maximum size determined by genetics, or a colony of organisms may release waste which is ultimately toxic to the colony once it exceeds a certain population.

**Density-Dependent Regulation:**
In population ecology, density-dependent processes occur when population growth rates are regulated by the density of a population. These processes can work through various mechanisms, including negative density-dependent restrictions that limit growth at higher population densities.

**Limiting Factors:**
In population ecology, a regulating factor, also known as a limiting factor, is something that keeps a population at equilibrium (neither increasing nor decreasing in size over time).(no content)Common limiting factor resources are environmental features that limit the growth, abundance, or distribution of an organism or a population of organisms in an ecosystem.

**Carrying Capacity:**
In a population, carrying capacity is known as the maximum population size of the species that the environment can sustain, which is determined by resources available.

**Self-Organization in Population Dynamics:**
The mathematical biologist Stuart Kauffman and other structuralists have suggested that self-organization may play roles alongside natural selection in three areas of evolutionary biology, namely population dynamics, molecular evolution, and morphogenesis.

These mechanisms work together to regulate population sizes and maintain ecological balance within environments.

Web search results for query: "Macroecology patterns"

Links: [{"title":"Macroecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroecology"},{"title":"Glossary of ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Glossary_of_ecology"},{"title":"Scaling pattern of occupancy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scaling_pattern_of_occupancy"},{"title":"Macroevolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroevolution"},{"title":"Microbial biogeography - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Microbial_biogeography"},{"title":"Outline of ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Outline_of_ecology"},{"title":"Soil ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terrestrial_ecology"},{"title":"Spatial ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spatial_ecology"},{"title":"Ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecology"},{"title":"Ecosystem ecology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_ecology"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about macroecology patterns:

## Overview of Macroecology

Macroecology is a subfield in ecology that investigates empirical patterns and mechanistic processes by which the particulate components of complex ecological systems generate emergent structures and dynamics. Unlike traditional ecology, which focuses on local and small-scale interactions, macroecology seeks to identify general emergent patterns within and across spatial and temporal scales.

## Key Patterns in Macroecology

Critical areas of interest within macroecology include the study of species richness, latitudinal gradients in species diversity, the species-area curve, range size, body size, and species abundance.(no content)The relationship between abundance and range size—exploring why some species are widespread and abundant while others are restricted and less common—has been a focal area of macroecological research.

## Statistical Order in Ecological Systems

One of the main tenets of macroecology is that, despite the apparent complexity and randomness of ecological systems, they exhibit a significant degree of order. This order is particularly evident in statistical patterns related to organism interactions, their relationships with the environment, and the emergent structures and dynamics of ecological systems.

## Spatial Patterns

In spatial ecology and macroecology, the scaling pattern of occupancy (SPO), also known as the area-of-occupancy (AOO), is the way in which species distribution changes across spatial scales.

The research shows that macroecology reveals consistent, measurable patterns that emerge when ecological systems are studied at broader scales and over larger spatial areas.

Web search results for query: "Biodiversity loss"

Links: [{"title":"Biodiversity loss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_loss"},{"title":"Biodiversity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity"},{"title":"No net loss - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_net_loss"},{"title":"Conservation biology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conservation_biology"},{"title":"Biodiversity of Guatemala - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_of_Guatemala"},{"title":"Habitat fragmentation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecosystem_fragmentation"},{"title":"No net loss environmental policy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/No_net_loss_environmental_policy"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about biodiversity loss:

## Overview

Biodiversity is defined as the "totality of genes, species and ecosystems of a region". All contemporary biodiversity loss has been attributed to human activities.

## Scale and Severity

The current biodiversity crisis is unprecedented. The current rate of global biodiversity loss is estimated to be 100 to 1000 times higher than the naturally occurring background extinction rate, faster than at any other time in human history. A 2022 study found that roughly 30% of species "have been globally threatened or driven extinct since the year 1500", and research published in 2023 found that out of 70,000 species, about 48% are facing decreasing populations due to human activities, while only 3% are seeing an increase in populations.

## Primary Causes

Many scientists say that the main reason for biodiversity loss is a growing human population because this leads to human overpopulation and excessive consumption. However, habitat destruction (often for expansion of agriculture), not climate change, is currently the bigger driver of biodiversity loss.

## Conservation Efforts

The UN Convention on Biological Diversity aims to prevent biodiversity loss and to conserve wilderness areas. However, a 2020 United Nations Environment Programme report found that most of these efforts had failed to meet their goals.

A 2022 study found that roughly 30% of species "have been globally threatened or driven extinct since the year 1500", and research published in 2023 found that out of 70,000 species, about 48% are facing decreasing populations due to human activities, while only 3% are seeing an increase in populations.

## Primary Causes

Many scientists say that the main reason for biodiversity loss is a growing human population because this leads to human overpopulation and excessive consumption. However, habitat destruction (often for expansion of agriculture), not climate change, is currently the bigger driver of biodiversity loss.

## Conservation Efforts

The UN Convention on Biological Diversity aims to prevent biodiversity loss and to conserve wilderness areas. However, a 2020 United Nations Environment Programme report found that most of these efforts had failed to meet their goals.

I've found comprehensive information about competition in ecology and biology. Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Competition in Ecology

In community ecology, competition within and between members of a species is an important biological interaction.(no content)Competition within, between, and among species is one of the most important forces in biology, especially in the field of ecology.

## Types of Competition

Competition among members of the same species is known as intraspecific competition, while competition between individuals of different species is known as interspecific competition.(no content)Interspecific competition is a form of competition in which individuals of different species compete for the same resources in an ecosystem (e.g. food or living space).(no content)Intraspecific competition is an interaction in population ecology, whereby members of the same species compete for limited resources.

## Mechanisms of Competition

There are three major mechanisms of competition: interference, exploitation, and apparent competition. Interference and exploitation competition can be classed as "real" forms of competition, while apparent competition is not, as organisms do not share a resource, but instead share a predator.

## Forms of Resource Competition

Scramble competition involves a relatively even distribution of resources among a population as all individuals exploit a common resource pool. In contrast, contest competition is the uneven distribution of resources and occurs when hierarchies in a population influence the amount of resource each individual receives.

## Competitive Exclusion Principle

The competitive exclusion principle, sometimes referred to as Gause's law, is a proposition that two species which compete for the same limited resource cannot coexist at constant population sizes.

Links: [{"title":"Logistic function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function"},{"title":"Logistic growth model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Logistic_growth_model&redirect=no"},{"title":"Generalised logistic function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalised_logistic_function"},{"title":"Ricker model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ricker_model"},{"title":"Gompertz function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gompertz_function"},{"title":"Competitive Lotka–Volterra equations","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_Lotka–Volterra_equations"},{"title":"Population dynamics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_dynamics"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Modelling Wikipedia's growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Modelling_Wikipedia's_growth"},{"title":"Population growth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_growth"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about the logistic growth model:

## Definition and Origin

The logistic function was introduced in a series of three papers by Pierre François Verhulst between 1838 and 1847, who devised it as a model of population growth by adjusting the exponential growth model.

## How It Works

The initial stage of growth is approximately exponential (geometric); then, as saturation begins, the growth slows to linear (arithmetic), and at maturity, growth approaches the limit with an exponentially decaying gap, like the initial stage in reverse.

## Mathematical Form

The logistic equation is expressed as dN/dt = rN(1 - N/K), where N is the population size, r is the intrinsic rate of natural increase, and K is the carrying capacity of the population.

## Key Components

In the logistic population model, x is the size of the population at a given time, r is inherent per-capita growth rate, and K is the carrying capacity.

## Applications

The logistic growth model has diverse applications:
- A typical application of the logistic equation is a common model of population growth, where the rate of reproduction is proportional to both the existing population and the amount of available resources
- Another application of logistic curve is in medicine, where the logistic differential equation can be used to model the growth of tumors
- The logistic function is usually used in a descriptive or phenomenological manner in epidemiology because it fits well not only to the early exponential rise, but to the eventual levelling off of a pandemic as the population develops a herd immunity

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks are complete. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Paper Analysis Complete

**Paper Classification:** `contribution`

This paper proposes a novel theoretical framework resolving the diversity-stability debate in ecology.

**Key Entities Extracted (9 triples):**

1. **Species diversity** - Used as foundational concept
2. **Ecological stability** - Core phenomenon being explained
3. **Power law** - Novel method proposed (sublinear scaling)
4. **Density dependence** - Novel mechanism proposed (self-regulation)
5. **Competition (biology)** - Used to analyze interaction dynamics
6. **Logistic function** - Used as contrast model
7. **Competitive exclusion principle** - Used classical principle addressed
8. **Biodiversity loss** - Problem motivation (task/context)
9. **Macroecology** - Large-scale patterns predicted

**Validation Status:** ✅ All checks passed

The triples_output.json file has been successfully populated with all entities, their relationships (uses/proposes), entity types, Wikipedia URLs, and relevance statements.

Sources:
- [Species diversity](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Species_diversity)
- [Ecological stability](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ecological_stability)
- [Power law](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Power_law)
- [Density dependence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Density_dependence)
- [Competition (biology)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competition_(biology))
- [Logistic function](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logistic_function)
- [Competitive exclusion principle](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Competitive_exclusion_principle)
- [Biodiversity loss](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Biodiversity_loss)
- [Macroecology](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macroecology)
